Hi John,

> Hi again,
> Since I'm here looking at things in the what not to crawl list,
> here is something that would certainly make my life happier.
> 
> Whenever I get a 'please don't touch my site', cause I don't
> know how to spell robots.txt (ok, that's mean, but most of them
> are just not the best thought out messages)
> 
> I immediately put that site in a nocrawl.surt.
> Then, eventually, I checkpoint, stop, and recover the job,
> to resume.

You don't need to do this since there is an option to re-read 
seeds/exclude files on any settings change.

I suggest the following:.
Use DecideRuleSequence.
Add acceptIfSurtPrefixed (SurtPrefixedDecideRule) where decision is set 
to ACCEPT.
Add rejectIfSurtPrefixed (SurtPrefixedDecideRule) where decision is set 
to REJECT, and the surts-source-file is exclude-surts.txt or similar. 
Set rebuild-on-reconfig to true.

If rebuild-on-reconfig is set to true, every time you load settings 
(click on Settings tab and then on Finished), the source file is re-read 
from the disk and internal data structures are re-populated. Be aware 
that if you have a large source file (millions of lines) it might take 
some time to reconfigure the crawl.

This way, you can just pause, 'touch' settings and resume.

> Something akin to re-read seeds.txt would be simply wonderful here.
> Re-read/apply the nocrawl.surt would save hours of time.
> 
> Its interesting, for some time now, the problems have not been what to
> crawl, they are what not to crawl.

Hope this helps.
